wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 8/28/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Employee Feedback Is The Killer App: A New Market Emerges

Employee engagement continues to be a top priority for businesses and at the same time, remains one of the hardest problems to solve, with only 30% of employees engaged in the U.S., according to Gallup. To make things more difficult, the engagement problem is only getting harder to solve as employees are more empowered, mobile and demanding. In response, a new market has emerged in the form of employee feedback apps, which are shaking up the corporate world, and redefining how organizations manage their employees.

Social Good Meets Business Strategy: Putting Your Signature on CSR

“According to the Conference Board, 76 percent of companies are measuring their societal impact, but only 18 percent of those have been doing so for five or more years, signifying an incredibly fast pace of change.” With such rapid change, many organizations have yet to commit to a specific focus for their CSR programs, yet 70 percent of companies say they want to develop a “flagship program”. How do companies get started in developing signature CSR initiatives? The first step is to think holistically, and then focus on syncing your program to key business strategies.

Amazon’s No Outlier: The Science Behind Broken Work Cultures

While the debate continues around Amazon’s workplace culture from the recent New York Times expos , the article has led to a resurgence of focus around the topic. Organizations still struggle to create an engaged, healthy and productive workforces, a recent study suggests that when an employee’s reasons for working are closely aligned to the work itself, performance spikes. The researchers group their findings into six fundamental motives (play, purpose, potential, emotional pressure, economic pressure and inertia) to explain why people are motivated to do anything.

CEOs Can’t Give Feedback Only to Their Direct Reports

Among the many contributing factors that took Campbell Soup Company from having one of the lowest employee engagement scores on the Fortune 500 to one of highest is through their commitment to management development. Campbell trains their managers’who account for 70% of variance in employee engagement’through top line leadership discussions that bring together the manager, their supervisor and their direct report, to form a specific plan and provide the necessary resources to build great managers.

Why Great CEOs Do Yoga with their Employees

To increase engagement among employees, CEOs are stepping out of their offices and away from water cooler small talk to form meaningful connections with their employees. In addition to improving healthy behavior at work, fitness-based activities can build a culture of motivation, facilitate teamwork, provide perspective, and improve employee engagement and loyalty.
